Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Experience of Food Insecurity in the Sociocultural Context

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Florida doctoral student Douglas A. Monroe, supervised by Dr. Clarence C. Gravlee, will undertake a six-month investigation of food insecurity. Globally, food insecurity is driven largely by food scarcity, but in the United States some people suffer from food insecurity even though food is abundant. The project will address four related exploratory questions: (1) How do African Americans who vary in terms of their economic resources, neighborhood context, and household composition experience food insecurity over time?; (2) in what ways does food insecurity mediate their dietary behaviors?; (3) what social, physical, and macro-level forces influence food insecurity?; and (4) what sociocultural and environmental factors distinguish African Americans who experience food insecurity from those who do not?

To address these questions the Co-PI will recruit a sub-sample of 32 African Americans who were randomly selected to participate in a broader epidemiological study and conduct a series of in-depth ethnographic interviews over the course of six months. At two-month intervals the Co-PI will visit respondents and elicit information about their household and neighborhood food environments, experiences of food insecurity, coping strategies, and also assess their dietary behaviors using a mixed methods approach. By conducting three interviews with each respondent over the study period, the Co-PI will be able to track seasonal variation and identify the corresponding variables associated with food insecurity.

Applying an ecological framework to the study of food insecurity and focusing on the sociocultural dimensions of food will help to explain differences in food security status among African Americans. The results will serve to disentangle the experience of food insecurity from food insufficiency, generate new hypotheses about the causes and consequences of food insecurity, and identify variables that should be considered in future research.

Tallahassee represents a locale with substantial interest in neighborhood food environments as they relate to food security and nutritional health. Various organizations and community-academic partnerships such as the Tallahassee Food Network (TFN) and the Health Equity Alliance of Tallahassee (HEAT) have promoted sustainable food, urban gardening, and better nutritional health. Through the dissemination of its findings, this project will improve the representation of historical underrepresented groups in food security studies and increase the scientific knowledge of scholars, policymakers, and community organizations such that they can advance their goals and activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used a multi-method approach to explore the experience of food insecurity in sociocultural context. The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) defines food insecurity as a state in which “consistent access to adequate food is limited by a lack of money and other resources at times during the year”. When people experience anxiety or stress about being able to meet their food needs, or when they are experiencing hunger because of a lack of food, they are considered to be food insecure. The USDA estimates that more than 17 million households in the U.S. experienced food insecurity at some point during the 2014 calendar year. Food insecurity is hypothesized to be linked to a wide variety of negative physical and mental health outcomes in the U.S. and across the world.

While all people share a biological need to eat, food also plays roles in their lives that are not directly related to nutrition. The key intuition of this project was that it was necessary to understand how people think and feel about food, and how it fits in to their daily lives in order to understand why some people experience food in security while others do not even in the absence of food shortages such as those that often occur in developing nations.

Using participant observation, semi-structured interviews, food frequency surveys and grocery receipts submitted by respondents during the study period, we found that there were substantial differences in food acquisition and food consumption between food secure and food insecure respondents. Food secure respondents tended to obtain a fairly broad range of foods (high dietary diversity) from a narrow range of food retailers (often in or around their neighborhoods). By contrast, respondents who experienced food insecurity tended to get a narrower range of foods (lower dietary diversity) from a broader range of retailers (often travelling far outside of their neighborhoods looking for the best deals they could find). Despite the fact that food insecure respondents went to great lengths to try to save money on groceries, the food receipts indicated that food insecure respondents spent approximately the same amount of money on their monthly grocery bills as the food secure respondents.

 Semi-structured interviews with respondents suggested that there were a number of differences between the food secure and the food insecure respondent in terms of how they conceptualized their relationships with food. For instance, the food secure respondents tended to discuss food in terms of fond memories and positive experiences, while respondents who experienced food insecurity framed their relationships with food as a struggle to avoid hunger and to adequately provide for their children and families. One of the most important differences that emerged in the semi-structured interviews was the frustration that food insecure respondents experienced in terms of their inability to share food with others, or to afford certain foods that had special meanings for them. The interviews revealed that respondents’ sense of food security was more complicated than simply having the food necessary to meet minimal nutritional needs.  

Several macro-level events occurred during the study period that impacted the food security of respondents. The first event was the federal government shutdown in October 2013. Several respondents who were employed by the state of Florida at the time were furloughed or required to work without pay during the course of the shutdown. This made it difficult for those respondents to meet basic needs including food needs during the shutdown period.
